Answer

  • For z > > L z>>L z>>L expect to get E = z ^ k λ L / z 2 \mathbf{E} = \hat{z}k\lambda L/z^2 E=z^kλL/z2, where λ L \lambda L λL is total charge on line.

  • E z E_z Ez​ should be half that for a line that extends from − L -L −L to L L L

  • As z z z increases, ratio of E x / E z E_x/E_z Ex​/Ez​ should decrease.

  • As z z z decreases, ratio of E x / E z E_x/E_z Ex​/Ez​ should increase.

  • As z z z approaches zero, E E E should become infinite (eventually sitting on top of a charge).

  • As λ \lambda λ approaches zero, E x E_x Ex​ and E y E_y Ey​ should approach zero.

E = − k λ ∫ 0 L x ′ d x ′ ( x ′ 2 + z 2 ) 3 / 2 x ^ + k λ z ∫ 0 L d x ′ ( x ′ 2 + z 2 ) 3 / 2 z ^ \displaystyle\mathbf{E}= -k\lambda \int_0^L\frac{x'dx'}{(x'^2+z^2)^{3/2}}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + k\lambda z\int_0^L\frac{dx'}{(x'^2+z^2)^{3/2}}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E=−kλ∫0L​(x′2+z2)3/2x′dx′​x^+kλz∫0L​(x′2+z2)3/2dx′​z^

E = k λ z [ ( − 1 + z z 2 + L 2 ) x ^ + ( L z 2 + L 2 ) z ^ ] \displaystyle\mathbf{E} = \frac{k\lambda}{z}\left[\left(-1+\frac{z}{\sqrt{z^2+L^2}}\right)\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \left(\frac{L}{\sqrt{z^2+L^2}}\right)\hat{\mathbf{z}}\right] E=zkλ​[(−1+z2+L2​z​)x^+(z2+L2​L​)z^]

0.1 Line of Charge

A line of charge with charge density of λ \lambda λ extends from − L -L −L to − l -l −l on the x x x-axis; A second line of charge with charge density of λ \lambda λ extends from l l l to L L L on the x x x-axis; L > 0 L>0 L>0 and l > 0 l>0 l>0.

  1. Sketch electric field lines

  2. Find E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis in terms of constants times a single integral

  3. Find V V V on the z z z-axis in terms of constants times a single integral

  4. At the origin, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E?

  5. When l ≃ L l\simeq L l≃L and z > > L z>>L z>>L, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis, and why?

  6. When L > > l L>> l L>>l and z > > l z>>l z>>l, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis, and why?

All final equations should be expressed in terms of k , λ , l , L , x , y , z k,\lambda,l,L,x,y,z k,λ,l,L,x,y,z and cartesian unit vectors.

Answers to 2.,4.-6.

E = − k λ ∫ l L x ′ d x ′ ( z 2 + x ′ 2 ) 3 / 2 x ^ + k λ z ∫ l L d x ′ ( z 2 + x ′ 2 ) 3 / 2 z ^ + k λ ∫ − l − L x ′ d x ′ ( z 2 + x ′ 2 ) 3 / 2 x ^ + k λ z ∫ − l − L d x ′ ( z 2 + x ′ 2 ) 3 / 2 z ^ \begin{align} \mathbf{E} = &-k\lambda \int_l^L\frac{x'dx'}{(z^2+x'^2)^{3/2}}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + k\lambda z\int_l^L\frac{dx'}{(z^2+x'^2)^{3/2}}\hat{\mathbf{z}}\\ & +k\lambda \int_{-l}^{-L}\frac{x'dx'}{(z^2+x'^2)^{3/2}}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + k\lambda z\int_{-l}^{-L}\frac{dx'}{(z^2+x'^2)^{3/2}}\hat{\mathbf{z}} \end{align} E=​−kλ∫lL​(z2+x′2)3/2x′dx′​x^+kλz∫lL​(z2+x′2)3/2dx′​z^+kλ∫−l−L​(z2+x′2)3/2x′dx′​x^+kλz∫−l−L​(z2+x′2)3/2dx′​z^​​

Note that the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ terms are expected to cancel based on the symmetry argument given below. (This was not asked for, but if you want to show this mathematically, change the variable in the second x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ integral using the substitution u = − x u=-x u=−x).

  1. The electric field should be zero. Each charge at a position x x x has a charge at a position − x -x −x that creates an equal an opposite electric field at the origin.

  2. l ≃ L l\simeq L l≃L means the two lines of charge “look” like point charges at ± L \pm L ±L. Because z > > L z>>L z>>L, it also looks like the two point charges overlap at the origin. I expect the electric field to be proportional to z ^ / z 2 \hat{\mathbf{z}}/z^2 z^/z2. (If you wanted to go further, you could write that the charge at the origin would be 2 ( L − l ) λ 2(L-l)\lambda 2(L−l)λ, so the electric field would be 2 k ( L − l ) λ z ^ / z 2 2k(L-l)\lambda\hat{\mathbf{z}}/z^2 2k(L−l)λz^/z2.)

  3. In this case, the gap of 2 l 2l 2l between the lines of charge is not visible. So the solution should be the same as that for an infinite line of charge (which you should be able to compute using Gauss’ Law).

==== Step 1 ====

This is a line of charge, so the general relationship is d q ′ = λ d l ′ dq'=\lambda dl' dq′=λdl′.

In general, a differential element parallel to a line in the x − y x-y x−y plane can be written as

d l ′ = d x ′ x ^ + d y ′ y ^ d\mathbf{l}' = dx'\hat{\mathbf{x}} + dy'\hat{\mathbf{y}} dl′=dx′x^+dy′y^​

the magnitude of d l ′ d\mathbf{l}' dl′ is

d l ′ = ( d x ′ ) 2 + ( d y ′ ) 2 dl' = \sqrt{(dx')^2+(dy')^2} dl′=(dx′)2+(dy′)2​

factoring out d x ′ dx' dx′ gives a formula that may be familiar from a calculus course in which the the length of a curve is computed:

d l ′ = d x ′ 1 + ( d y ′ d x ′ ) 2 dl' = dx'\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{dy'}{dx'}\right)^2} dl′=dx′1+(dx′dy′​)2​

In this problem, we are not explicitly given d y ′ / d x ′ dy'/dx' dy′/dx′, but it can be derived by noting from a diagram that tan ⁡ α = y ′ / x ′ \tan\alpha = y'/x' tanα=y′/x′ so that

y ′ = x ′ tan ⁡ α y' = x'\tan\alpha y′=x′tanα

and so d y ′ / d x ′ = tan ⁡ α dy'/dx' = \tan\alpha dy′/dx′=tanα. Substitution gives

d l ′ = d x ′ 1 + ( d y ′ d x ′ ) 2 = d x ′ 1 + tan ⁡ 2 α dl' = dx'\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{dy'}{dx'}\right)^2}=dx'\sqrt{1+\tan^2\alpha} dl′=dx′1+(dx′dy′​)2​=dx′1+tan2α​

and finally an equation for d q ′ dq' dq′

d q ′ = λ d l ′ = d x ′ 1 + tan ⁡ 2 α dq'=\lambda dl'= dx'\sqrt{1+\tan^2\alpha} dq′=λdl′=dx′1+tan2α​

==== Step 2 ====

In general,

r = x x ^ + y y ^ + z z ^ \mathbf{r}=x\hat{\mathbf{x}}+y\hat{\mathbf{y}}+z\hat{\mathbf{z}} r=xx^+yy^​+zz^

r ′ = x ′ x ^ + y ′ y ^ + z ′ z ^ \mathbf{r}'=x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+y'\hat{\mathbf{y}}+z'\hat{\mathbf{z}} r′=x′x^+y′y^​+z′z^

for this problem, we only want to know r \mathbf{r} r for points on the y y y-axis, so x = 0 x=0 x=0 and z = 0 z=0 z=0 leaving

r = y y ^ \mathbf{r}=y\hat{\mathbf{y}} r=yy^​

the line of charge is in the x x x- y y y plane, so z ′ z' z′ is always zero, leaving

r ′ = x ′ x ^ + y ′ y ^ \mathbf{r}'=x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+y'\hat{\mathbf{y}} r′=x′x^+y′y^​

==== Step 3 ====

Write

E d q ′ ( x , y , z ) = d q ′ 4 π ϵ 0 r − r ′ ∣ r − r ′ ∣ 3 \mathbf{E}_{dq'}(x,y,z) = \frac{dq'}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|^3} Edq′​(x,y,z)=4πϵ0​dq′​∣r−r′∣3r−r′​

replacing d q ′ dq' dq′ with the differential found in Step 1, d q ′ = d x ′ 1 + tan ⁡ 2 α dq' = dx'\sqrt{1+\tan^2\alpha} dq′=dx′1+tan2α​, and using the reduced versions of r \mathbf{r} r and r ′ \mathbf{r}' r′ in Step 2. Noting that

r − r ′ = y y ^ − ( x ′ x ^ + y ′ y ^ ) \mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'=y\hat{\mathbf{y}}-\big(x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+y'\hat{\mathbf{y}}\big) r−r′=yy^​−(x′x^+y′y^​)

which can be rewritten as

r − r ′ = − x ′ x ^ + ( y − y ′ ) y ^ \mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'=-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(y-y')\hat{\mathbf{y}} r−r′=−x′x^+(y−y′)y^​

The magnitude is

∣ r − r ′ ∣ = ( − x ′ ) 2 + ( y − y ′ ) 2 = x ′ 2 + ( y − y ′ ) 2 |\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|=\sqrt{(-x')^2 + (y-y')^2}=\sqrt{x'^2 + (y-y')^2} ∣r−r′∣=(−x′)2+(y−y′)2​=x′2+(y−y′)2​

and substitution gives

E d q ′ ( x , y , z ) = d x ′ 1 + tan ⁡ 2 α 4 π ϵ 0 − x ′ x ^ + ( y − y ′ ) y ^ ( x ′ 2 + ( y − y ′ ) 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}_{dq'}(x,y,z) = \frac{dx'\sqrt{1+\tan^2\alpha}}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(y-y')\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\big(x'^2 + (y-y')^2\big)^{3/2}} Edq′​(x,y,z)=4πϵ0​dx′1+tan2α​​(x′2+(y−y′)2)3/2−x′x^+(y−y′)y^​​

==== Step 4 ====

The final step is to integrate this equation from x ′ = 0 x'=0 x′=0 to x ′ = a x'=a x′=a:

E ( y ) all  d q ′ = ∫ 0 a d x ′ 1 + tan ⁡ 2 α 4 π ϵ 0 − x ′ x ^ + ( y − y ′ ) y ^ ( x ′ 2 + ( y − y ′ ) 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}(y)_{\text{all }dq'} = \int_0^{a}\frac{dx'\sqrt{1+\tan^2\alpha}}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(y-y')\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\big(x'^2 + (y-y')^2\big)^{3/2}} E(y)all dq′​=∫0a​4πϵ0​dx′1+tan2α​​(x′2+(y−y′)2)3/2−x′x^+(y−y′)y^​​

In Step 1, d l ′ dl' dl′ was found in terms of d x ′ dx' dx′, so all of the primed variables need to be written in terms of x ′ x' x′. Using y ′ = x ′ tan ⁡ α y'=x'\tan\alpha y′=x′tanα gives an equation that is ready for integration

E ( y ) all  d q ′ = ∫ 0 a d x ′ 1 + tan ⁡ 2 α 4 π ϵ 0 − x ′ x ^ + ( y − x ′ tan ⁡ α ) y ^ ( x ′ 2 + ( y − x ′ tan ⁡ α ) 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}(y)_{\text{all }dq'} = \int_0^{a}\frac{dx'\sqrt{1+\tan^2\alpha}}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(y-x'\tan\alpha)\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\big(x'^2 + (y-x'\tan\alpha)^2\big)^{3/2}} E(y)all dq′​=∫0a​4πϵ0​dx′1+tan2α​​(x′2+(y−x′tanα)2)3/2−x′x^+(y−x′tanα)y^​​

To solve this, if desired, start by factoring out the constant terms and write the equation in terms of three integrals with y y y treated as a constant with respect to the integration.

==== Step 5 ====

Two checks were already made.

If the integral was performed, we could use the answer from Griffiths Example 2.2 to compare the answer from this problem for a special value of y y y: the y y y-value where a line drawn from the center of, and perpendicular to, the line of charge crosses the y y y-axis.

0.2 Line of Charge at Angle

A line of charge with a charge density of λ \lambda λ lies along the line z = m x z=m x z=mx, where m m m is a constant, and extends from x = − a x=-a x=−a to x = a x=a x=a.

  1. What is the expected (general) direction of E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z)? How is this direction expected to change as z z z increases?

  2. For z > > a z >> a z>>a, what should E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) approach? (Give exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system given in the problem.)

  3. For z < < a z << a z<<a, what should E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) approach? (Give exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system given in the problem.)

  4. Find an integral that must be solved to find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z). See the [[F19/Notes#Continuous_Charge_Distributions|note in Step 4]] about integrals with primed variables that don’t have a corresponding primed differential variable.

Answer

This problem is similar to a problem in [[F19/Notes#Continuous_Charge_Distributions|sample problems for continuous charge distributions in the notes]]. The difference is that in the sample problem

  1. the line was at an angle α \alpha α in the x − y x-y x−y plane

  2. the points of interest were along the y y y-axis

and in this problem

  1. the line follows the equation z = m x z=mx z=mx so that the length of the line is 2 a 2 + ( a m ) 2 = 2 a 1 + m 2 2\sqrt{a^2+(am)^2}=2a\sqrt{1+m^2} 2a2+(am)2​=2a1+m2​

  2. the points of interest are along the z z z-axis

Instead of the relationship y ′ = x ′ tan ⁡ α y'=x'\tan\alpha y′=x′tanα, the relationship is z ′ = m x ′ z'=mx' z′=mx′. So anywhere tan ⁡ α \tan\alpha tanα appears in the sample problem, it can be replaced with m m m and any y y y, y ′ y' y′, and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ can be replaced with z z z, z ′ z' z′, and z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^, respectively. The final answer is

E ( z ) = ∫ − a a d x ′ 1 + m 2 4 π ϵ 0 − x ′ x ^ + ( z − m x ′ ) z ^ ( x ′ 2 + ( z − m x ′ ) 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}(z) = \int_{-a}^{a}\frac{dx'\sqrt{1+m^2}}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(z-mx')\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{\big(x'^2 + (z-mx')^2\big)^{3/2}} E(z)=∫−aa​4πϵ0​dx′1+m2​​(x′2+(z−mx′)2)3/2−x′x^+(z−mx′)z^​

For question #2., at z ≫ a z\gg a z≫a, the answer of “0” is technically correct, but the problem statement asks for an equation in terms of the parameters given in the problem. Examples of this were given in class, in example 2.2 of Griffiths, and in the notes. The answer I was looking for is E ( z ) = y ^ k q ′ / y 2 \mathbf{E}(z)=\hat{\mathbf{y}}kq'/y^2 E(z)=y^​kq′/y2, where q ′ = λ L = λ 2 a 2 + ( a m ) 2 = λ 2 a 1 + m 2 q'=\lambda L = \lambda 2\sqrt{a^2+(am)^2}=\lambda 2a\sqrt{1+m^2} q′=λL=λ2a2+(am)2​=λ2a1+m2​. So that in terms of the parameters given in the problem statement,

E ( z ) = k λ 2 a 1 + m 2 y 2 y ^ \mathbf{E}(z)=\frac{k\lambda 2a\sqrt{1+m^2}}{y^2}\hat{\mathbf{y}} E(z)=y2kλ2a1+m2​​y^​

For question #3., at z ≪ a z\ll a z≪a, the point is just above the center of the line and the system “looks” like an infinite line of charge, so the infinite line of charge equation applies. The electric field at this point will be perpendicular to the line. If s s s is the perpendicular distance from the center of the line, then E ( s ) = ( 1 / 2 π ϵ o ) s ^ / s \mathbf{E}(s)=(1/2\pi\epsilon_o)\hat{\mathbf{s}}/s E(s)=(1/2πϵo​)s^/s. Some students used this equation with z z z instead of s s s.

To get an exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system of the problem, one needs to write s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^ and s s s in terms of parameters and the coordinate system given in the problem of x x x, z z z, and m m m: s = − z ( − x ^ + z ^ / m ) \mathbf{s}=-z(-\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\hat{\mathbf{z}}/m) s=−z(−x^+z^/m). I gave full credit if it was recognized that at z ≪ a z\ll a z≪a, the field should be perpendicular to the line. Some students said the field would be zero because these points are on the line - this is not correct - z ≪ a z\ll a z≪a means just above the infinitely thin line; only z = 0 z = 0 z=0 would be exactly on the line.

0.3 Line of Charge with Parabolic Shape

A line of charge with a charge density of λ \lambda λ has a parabolic shape of z = x 2 z=x^2 z=x2 and extends from x = − a x=-a x=−a to x = a x=a x=a.

  1. What is the expected direction of E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z)?

  2. For z > > a z >> a z>>a, what should E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) approach? (Give exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system given in the problem.)

  3. Find an integral that must be solved to find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z). See the [[F19/Notes#Continuous_Charge_Distributions|note in Step 4]] about integrals with primed variables that don’t have a corresponding primed differential variable.

Answer

  1. For z > 0 z>0 z>0, expect E \mathbf{E} E to be in + z ^ +\hat{\mathbf{z}} +z^ direction (I gave full credit for this answer, but some correctly noted that there may be a point for small enough z where it is actually in − z ^ -\hat{\mathbf{z}} −z^ direction). For z > 0 z>0 z>0, expect E \mathbf{E} E to be in − z ^ -\hat{\mathbf{z}} −z^ direction. The on the z-axis, the electric field has no component in the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ direction because a charge at position x = x o x=x_o x=xo​ produces an electric field with a component in the − x ^ -\hat{\mathbf{x}} −x^ direction that is canceled by that from a charge at x = − x o x=-x_o x=−xo​. The electric field component in the z z z-direction for both of these charges are in the + z +z +z direction. (Draw this.)

  2. When z > > a z>>a z>>a, the distance from all d q ′ s dq's dq′s to the point of interest at z z z is approximately z z z and so Coulomb’s Law for a charge Q Q Q at the origin applies: E = k Q ′ / z 2 E=kQ'/z^2 E=kQ′/z2, where Q ′ Q' Q′ is the total charge on the line. Q ′ Q' Q′ needs to be written in terms of the parameters of the problem - it is Q ′ = λ L Q' = \lambda L Q′=λL where L L L is the length of the line that will depend on a a a. Computing the length of the line requires integration and I gave full credit is this was recognized but L L L was not calculated. The general formula for the length of a line that follows a path P \mathcal{P} P is

L = ∫ P d l L = \int_{\mathcal{P}} dl L=∫P​dl

The integration requires writing d l dl dl and the limits of integration in terms of a coordinate system.

The general formula for a differential element in cartesian coordinates is

d l = d x x ^ + d z z ^ d\mathbf{l} = dx\hat{\mathbf{x}} + dz\hat{\mathbf{z}} dl=dxx^+dzz^

which has a magnitude

d l = ( d x ) 2 + ( d z ) 2 dl = \sqrt{(dx)^2+(dz)^2} dl=(dx)2+(dz)2​

factoring out d x dx dx gives a formula that may be familiar from path integration in a calculus course

d l = d x 1 + ( d z d x ) 2 dl = dx\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{dz}{dx}\right)^2} dl=dx1+(dxdz​)2​

so the length of the differential element depends on the slope of the line d z / d x dz/dx dz/dx. For this particular problem, the line follows the path P \mathcal{P} P according to the equation z = x 2 z=x^2 z=x2, so d z / d x = 2 x dz/dx = 2x dz/dx=2x. Substitution gives

d l = d x 1 + 4 x 2 dl = dx\sqrt{1+4x^2} dl=dx1+4x2​

This d l dl dl can now be used to perform the integration of the general equation

L = ∫ P d l = ∫ − a a d x 1 + 4 x 2 L = \int_{\mathcal{P}} dl = \int_{-a}^{a}dx\sqrt{1+4x^2} L=∫P​dl=∫−aa​dx1+4x2​

The integral can be perfomed using a x = ( tan ⁡ u ) / 2 x=(\tan u)/2 x=(tanu)/2 substitution and appears in many references - the key that I am looking in solutions is the recognition that computing the total charge in terms of the parameters given requires integration and the set-up of the integral.

  1. Step 1

d l dl dl was already computed previously and so

d q ′ = λ d l ′ = d x ′ 1 + 4 x ′ 2 dq'=\lambda dl'= dx'\sqrt{1+4x'^2} dq′=λdl′=dx′1+4x′2​

where primes are used following the convention that position variables associated with charges are primed.

Step 2

In general,

r = x x ^ + y y ^ + z z ^ \mathbf{r}=x\hat{\mathbf{x}}+y\hat{\mathbf{y}}+z\hat{\mathbf{z}} r=xx^+yy^​+zz^

r ′ = x ′ x ^ + y ′ y ^ + z ′ z ^ \mathbf{r}'=x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+y'\hat{\mathbf{y}}+z'\hat{\mathbf{z}} r′=x′x^+y′y^​+z′z^

for this problem, we only want to know r \mathbf{r} r for points on the z z z-axis, so x = 0 x=0 x=0 and y = 0 y=0 y=0 leaving

r = z z ^ \mathbf{r}=z\hat{\mathbf{z}} r=zz^

the line of charge is in the x x x- z z z plane, so y ′ y' y′ is always zero, leaving

r ′ = x ′ x ^ + z ′ z ^ \mathbf{r}'=x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+z'\hat{\mathbf{z}} r′=x′x^+z′z^

Step 3.

Write

E d q ′ ( x , y , z ) = d q ′ 4 π ϵ 0 r − r ′ ∣ r − r ′ ∣ 3 \mathbf{E}_{dq'}(x,y,z) = \frac{dq'}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|^3} Edq′​(x,y,z)=4πϵ0​dq′​∣r−r′∣3r−r′​

replacing d q ′ dq' dq′ with the differential found in Step 1, d q ′ = λ d x ′ 1 + 4 x ′ 2 dq' = \lambda dx'\sqrt{1+4x'^2} dq′=λdx′1+4x′2​, and using the reduced versions of r \mathbf{r} r and r ′ \mathbf{r}' r′ in Step 2. Noting that

r − r ′ = z z ^ − ( x ′ x ^ + z ′ z ^ ) \mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'=z\hat{\mathbf{z}}-\big(x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+z'\hat{\mathbf{z}}\big) r−r′=zz^−(x′x^+z′z^)

which can be rewritten as

r − r ′ = − x ′ x ^ + ( z − z ′ ) z ^ \mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'=-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(z-z')\hat{\mathbf{z}} r−r′=−x′x^+(z−z′)z^

The magnitude is

∣ r − r ′ ∣ = ( − x ′ ) 2 + ( z − z ′ ) 2 = x ′ 2 + ( z − z ′ ) 2 |\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|=\sqrt{(-x')^2 + (z-z')^2}=\sqrt{x'^2 + (z-z')^2} ∣r−r′∣=(−x′)2+(z−z′)2​=x′2+(z−z′)2​

and substitution gives

E d q ′ ( x , y , z ) = λ d x ′ 1 + 4 x ′ 2 4 π ϵ 0 − x ′ x ^ + ( z − z ′ ) z ^ ( x ′ 2 + ( z − z ′ ) 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}_{dq'}(x,y,z) = \frac{\lambda dx'\sqrt{1+4x'^2}}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(z-z')\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{\big(x'^2 + (z-z')^2\big)^{3/2}} Edq′​(x,y,z)=4πϵ0​λdx′1+4x′2​​(x′2+(z−z′)2)3/2−x′x^+(z−z′)z^​

Step 4.

The last step is to integrate from x ′ = − a x'=-a x′=−a to x ′ = a x'=a x′=a and to replace z ′ z' z′, which depends on the integration variable x ′ x' x′, using z ′ = x ′ 2 z'=x'^2 z′=x′2.

E ∗ all  d q ′ s ( x , y , z ) = ∫ ∗ − a a λ d x ′ 1 + 4 x ′ 2 4 π ϵ 0 − x ′ x ^ + ( z − x ′ 2 ) z ^ ( x ′ 2 + ( z − x ′ 2 ) 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}*{\text{all }dq's}(x,y,z) = \int*{-a}^{a}\frac{\lambda dx'\sqrt{1+4x'^2}}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(z-x'^2)\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{\big(x'^2 + (z-x'^2)^2\big)^{3/2}} E∗all dq′s(x,y,z)=∫∗−aa4πϵ0​λdx′1+4x′2​​(x′2+(z−x′2)2)3/2−x′x^+(z−x′2)z^​

Previously, it was claimed that the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^-component should be zero and so it is expected that the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ integral is zero. That the integral is zero can be seen by noting that that the function

f ( x ′ ) = x ′ 1 + 4 x ′ 2 ( x ′ 2 + ( z − x ′ 2 ) 2 ) 3 / 2 f(x') = \frac{x'\sqrt{1+4x'^2}}{\big(x'^2 + (z-x'^2)^2\big)^{3/2}} f(x′)=(x′2+(z−x′2)2)3/2x′1+4x′2​​

satisfies f ( x ′ ) = − f ( x ′ ) f(x')=-f(x') f(x′)=−f(x′) so that f f f is an “odd” function, which integrate to zero over a range from x ′ = − a x'=-a x′=−a to x ′ = + a x'=+a x′=+a. You may want to demonstrate this by plotting this function. (The argument here is similar to the argument that the integral of f ( x ) = x 3 f(x)=x^3 f(x)=x3 is zero - the integral of f ( x ) f(x) f(x) for x < 0 x<0 x<0 is equal and opposite to the integral for x > 0 x>0 x>0 so that the integral over a range x = − a x=-a x=−a to x = + a x=+a x=+a is zero.

0.4 Ring of Charge

A ring of charge with charge density of λ \lambda λ has a radius a a a, is centered at the origin, and lies in the x − y x-y x−y plane.

  1. Find V V V on the z z z-axis

  2. Find E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis

  3. When on the z z z-axis and for z < < a z<<a z<<a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E, and why?

  4. When z > > a z>>a z>>a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis, and why?

All final equations should be expressed in terms of k , λ , a k,\lambda,a k,λ,a using any coordinate system.

0.5 Ring of Charge

Write your answer on a blank sheet of paper of printer paper.

A ring of charge with charge density of λ \lambda λ has a radius a a a, is centered at the origin, and lies in the x − y x-y x−y plane.

  1. When z < < a z<<a z<<a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E (magnitude and direction) on the z z z-axis, and why*?

  2. When z > > a z>>a z>>a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E (magnitude and direction) on the z z z-axis, and why*?

  3. Find V V V on the z z z-axis (that is, find V ( z ) V(z) V(z)).

  4. Find E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis (that is, find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z)).

*That is, without doing any integration, what do you expect the answer to be like in these limits. I gave many examples of this in class.

All final equations should be expressed in terms of k k k or ϵ 0 , λ \epsilon_0,\lambda ϵ0​,λ, and a a a using any coordinate system.

[[Image:ring_of_charge.png|400px]]

Answer

1. Expect E = 0 \mathbf{E}=0 E=0 at the origin. One can find a d q dq dq on one side of the ring that has a d q dq dq on the other side of the ring that produces an electric field equal in magnitude and opposite in direction at the origin. A tiny distance above the origin, the electric field lines are nearly horizontal, so the z z z component should be nearly zero. So an acceptable answer is that the z z z component gets close to zero.

2. Field should be that of a charge q = 2 π a λ q=2\pi a\lambda q=2πaλ at the origin, so

E = 1 4 π ϵ 0 q z 2 z ^ = 1 4 π ϵ 0 2 π a λ z 2 z ^ = 1 2 ϵ 0 a λ z 2 z ^ = 2 k π a λ z 2 z ^ \mathbf{E} = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{q}{z^2}\hat{\mathbf{z}} = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{2\pi a\lambda}{z^2}\hat{\mathbf{z}} = \frac{1}{2\epsilon_0}\frac{a\lambda}{z^2}\hat{\mathbf{z}}=\frac{2k\pi a\lambda}{z^2}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E=4πϵ0​1​z2q​z^=4πϵ0​1​z22πaλ​z^=2ϵ0​1​z2aλ​z^=z22kπaλ​z^

The equation from part 4. gives this result if z > > a z>>a z>>a.

3. A clever way of solving this without doing any integration is to note that the work required to move a charge along the z z z-axis against the force due to the ring is the same as if all of the charge, 2 π a λ 2\pi a\lambda 2πaλ were concentrated at say x = a x=a x=a or y = a y=a y=a because the distance from a d q dq dq on the ring to a point on the z − z- z−axis is the same for all charges on the ring. In this case, the distance of the point charge to a point along the z-axis is ∣ r − r ′ ∣ = ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 |\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|=(a^2+z^2)^{1/2} ∣r−r′∣=(a2+z2)1/2. So

V = k q ∣ r − r ′ ∣ = k 2 π a λ ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 = λ a 2 ϵ 0 1 ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 V=\frac{kq}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|} = \frac{k 2\pi a\lambda}{(a^2+z^2)^{1/2}}=\frac{\lambda a }{2\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{(a^2+z^2)^{1/2}} V=∣r−r′∣kq​=(a2+z2)1/2k2πaλ​=2ϵ0​λa​(a2+z2)1/21​

The regular method of solution is to start with the general equation for electric potential due to a point charge V = q 4 π ϵ 0 1 ∣ r − r ′ ∣ V = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|} V=4πϵ0​q​∣r−r′∣1​

In terms of a differential charge, this is d V = d q 4 π ϵ 0 1 ∣ r − r ′ ∣ dV = \frac{dq}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|} dV=4πϵ0​dq​∣r−r′∣1​

From the given geometry, the point of interest is

r = z z ^ \mathbf{r} = z\hat{\mathbf{z}} r=zz^

and the location of the charge acting on the point of interest is

r ′ = a cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) x ^ + a sin ⁡ ( ϕ ) y ^ \mathbf{r}' = a\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{x}}+a\sin(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{y}} r′=acos(ϕ)x^+asin(ϕ)y^​

so

d V = d q 4 π ϵ 0 1 ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 dV = \frac{dq}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{(a^2+z^2)^{1/2}} dV=4πϵ0​dq​(a2+z2)1/21​

We want to integrate, so need to write d q dq dq in terms of coordinates. On the ring, a small piece has a length of a d ϕ a d\phi adϕ, so

d q = λ a d ϕ dq=\lambda a d\phi dq=λadϕ$

where ϕ \phi ϕ is the polar coordinate angle. This gives

V = ∫ 0 2 π λ a d ϕ 4 π ϵ 0 1 ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 V = \int_0^{2\pi}\frac{\lambda a d\phi}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{(a^2+z^2)^{1/2}} V=∫02π​4πϵ0​λadϕ​(a2+z2)1/21​

factoring out everything that does not depend on ϕ \phi ϕ gives

V = λ a 4 π ϵ 0 1 ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 ∫ 0 2 π d ϕ V = \frac{\lambda a }{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{(a^2+z^2)^{1/2}}\int_0^{2\pi}d\phi V=4πϵ0​λa​(a2+z2)1/21​∫02π​dϕ

so the final answer is

V = λ a 2 ϵ 0 1 ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 = 2 k π λ a ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 V = \frac{\lambda a }{2\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{(a^2+z^2)^{1/2}}=\frac{2k\pi\lambda a}{(a^2+z^2)^{1/2}} V=2ϵ0​λa​(a2+z2)1/21​=(a2+z2)1/22kπλa​

‘’’4. Find E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis (that is, find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z))’’’

The easy way to get the answer is to use

E = − ∇ V = − z ^ ∂ V / ∂ z = − z ^ ∂ ∂ z λ a 2 ϵ 0 1 ( a 2 + z 2 ) 1 / 2 \mathbf{E}=-\nabla V=-\hat{\mathbf{z}}\partial V/\partial z =-\hat{\mathbf{z}}\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\frac{\lambda a }{2\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{(a^2+z^2)^{1/2}} E=−∇V=−z^∂V/∂z=−z^∂z∂​2ϵ0​λa​(a2+z2)1/21​

Giving the final answer of E = λ a 2 ϵ 0 z z ^ ( z 2 + a 2 ) 3 / 2 = 2 k π λ a z z ^ ( z 2 + a 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}=\frac{\lambda a}{2\epsilon_0}\frac{z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{(z^2+a^2)^{3/2}}=2k\pi\lambda a\frac{z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{(z^2+a^2)^{3/2}} E=2ϵ0​λa​(z2+a2)3/2zz^​=2kπλa(z2+a2)3/2zz^​

Long answer:

General definition of electric field due to a point charge from Coulomb’s Law E = q 4 π ϵ 0 1 ∣ r − r ′ ∣ 2 r − r ′ ∣ r − r ′ ∣ \mathbf{E} = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|^2}\frac{\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|} E=4πϵ0​q​∣r−r′∣21​∣r−r′∣r−r′​

In terms of a differential charge, this is (1)  d E = d q 4 π ϵ 0 1 ∣ r − r ′ ∣ 2 r − r ′ ∣ r − r ′ ∣ \text{(1) }d\mathbf{E} = \frac{dq}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|^2}\frac{\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|} (1) dE=4πϵ0​dq​∣r−r′∣21​∣r−r′∣r−r′​

From the given geometry, the point of interest is r = z z ^ \mathbf{r} = z\hat{\mathbf{z}} r=zz^ and the location of the charge acting on the point of interest is r ′ = a cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) x ^ + a sin ⁡ ( ϕ ) y ^ \mathbf{r}' = a\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{x}}+a\sin(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{y}} r′=acos(ϕ)x^+asin(ϕ)y^​

Subtituting into (1) gives d E = d q 4 π ϵ 0 z z ^ − a cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) x ^ − a sin ⁡ ( ϕ ) y ^ ( z 2 + a 2 ) 3 / 2 d\mathbf{E}= \frac{dq}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{z\hat{\mathbf{z}}-a\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{x}}-a\sin(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{(z^2+a^2)^{3/2}} dE=4πϵ0​dq​(z2+a2)3/2zz^−acos(ϕ)x^−asin(ϕ)y^​​

We want to integrate, so need to write d q dq dq in terms of coordinates. On the ring, a small piece has a length of a d ϕ a d\phi adϕ, so d q = λ a d ϕ dq=\lambda a d\phi dq=λadϕ

where ϕ \phi ϕ is the polar coordinate angle. This gives E = ∫ 0 2 π λ d ϕ 4 π ϵ 0 z z ^ − a cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) x ^ − a sin ⁡ ( ϕ ) y ^ ( z 2 + a 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E} = \int_0^{2\pi}\frac{\lambda d\phi}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{z\hat{\mathbf{z}}-a\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{x}}-a\sin(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{(z^2+a^2)^{3/2}} E=∫02π​4πϵ0​λdϕ​(z2+a2)3/2zz^−acos(ϕ)x^−asin(ϕ)y^​​

Based on the symmetry argument that we can always find another d q dq dq that exactly cancels the horizontal component of a given d q dq dq, we expect the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ terms to be zero, so we can drop them. Or we can notice that after factoring out everything that does not depend on ϕ \phi ϕ, the integrals for the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ terms are cos ⁡ ϕ , d ϕ \cos\phi,d\phi cosϕ,dϕ and sin ⁡ ϕ , d ϕ \sin\phi,d\phi sinϕ,dϕ from 0 0 0 to 2 π 2\pi 2π, which are both zero.

Keeping only the z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^ term and factoring out everything that does not depend on ϕ \phi ϕ gives E = λ a 4 π ϵ 0 z z ^ ( z 2 + a 2 ) 3 / 2 ∫ 0 2 π d ϕ \mathbf{E} =\frac{\lambda a}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{(z^2+a^2)^{3/2}} \int_0^{2\pi}d\phi E=4πϵ0​λa​(z2+a2)3/2zz^​∫02π​dϕ

Final answer: E = λ 2 ϵ 0 a z ( z 2 + a 2 ) 3 / 2 z ^ \mathbf{E} = \frac{\lambda}{2\epsilon_0}\frac{az}{(z^2+a^2)^{3/2}}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E=2ϵ0​λ​(z2+a2)3/2az​z^

To check your answer to part 1., factor out a a a from the square root to get

E = λ 2 ϵ 0 a z a 3 ( 1 + a 2 / z 2 ) 3 / 2 z ^ = λ 2 a ϵ 0 z a z ^ \mathbf{E} = \frac{\lambda}{2\epsilon_0}\frac{az}{a^3(1+a^2/z^2)^{3/2}}\hat{\mathbf{z}} = \frac{\lambda}{2a\epsilon_0}\frac{z}{a}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E=2ϵ0​λ​a3(1+a2/z2)3/2az​z^=2aϵ0​λ​az​z^

When z / a ≪ 1 z/a \ll 1 z/a≪1, E ≃ 0 z ^ \mathbf{E} \simeq 0\hat{\mathbf{z}} E≃0z^.

0.9 Disk of Charge

A disk of charge with charge density of σ \sigma σ has a radius a a a, is centered at the origin, and lies in the x − y x-y x−y plane.

  1. Sketch electric field lines

  2. Find V V V on the z z z-axis in terms of constants times a single integral.

  3. Find E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis in terms of constants times one or more integrals.

  4. On the z z z-axis and for z < < a z<<a z<<a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E, and why?

  5. On the z z z-axis and for z > > a z>>a z>>a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E, and why?

  6. It does not technically make sense to ask “on the z z z-axis and for large z z z, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E?”. Why?

All final equations should be expressed in terms of k k k or ϵ 0 , σ \epsilon_0,\sigma ϵ0​,σ, and a a a using any coordinate system.

Answers to 3.-6.

3. There are three general ways to do this:

1. Starting from the basic formula for the electric field due to a charge d q dq dq and summing contributions from d q dq dqs at all locations on the disk. This will involve a double integral. 2. Integrating over contributions from rings of charge. This will involve a single integral over contributions of rings of different sizes and knowledge of the electric field due to a ring of charge. 3. Computing V V V first and using E = − ∇ V \mathbf{E}=-\nabla V E=−∇V.

I’ll follow method 1. and I’ll note that one of the formulas found as the solution is developed is the same one you would get if you started with 2. Method 3. would be useful if I asked you to solve the integral, which I am not going to do on an exam. (But there is a trick that I have not showed you that you could use on the exam where you can write V V V in terms of an integral and then differentiate it. If you want to know about this, ask me in person).

General definition of electric field due to a point charge from Coulomb’s Law E = q 4 π ϵ 0 1 ∣ r − r ′ ∣ 2 r − r ′ ∣ r − r ′ ∣ \mathbf{E} = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|^2}\frac{\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|} E=4πϵ0​q​∣r−r′∣21​∣r−r′∣r−r′​

In terms of a differential charge, this is (1)  d E = d q 4 π ϵ 0 1 ∣ r − r ′ ∣ 2 r − r ′ ∣ r − r ′ ∣ \text{(1) }d\mathbf{E} = \frac{dq}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|^2}\frac{\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|} (1) dE=4πϵ0​dq​∣r−r′∣21​∣r−r′∣r−r′​

From the given geometry, the point of interest is r = z z ^ \mathbf{r} = z\hat{\mathbf{z}} r=zz^ and the location of the charge acting on the point of interest is r ′ = ρ cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) x ^ + ρ sin ⁡ ( ϕ ) y ^ \mathbf{r}' = \rho\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\rho\sin(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{y}} r′=ρcos(ϕ)x^+ρsin(ϕ)y^​ Note that ρ \rho ρ is used in this equation to make r ′ \mathbf{r}' r′ depend on the radial distance of the charge d q dq dq. In the ring problem, a a a is used instead of r r r.

Subtituting into (1) gives d E = d q 4 π ϵ 0 z z ^ − ρ cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) x ^ − ρ cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) y ^ ( z 2 + ρ 2 ) 3 / 2 d\mathbf{E}= \frac{dq}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{z\hat{\mathbf{z}}-\rho\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{x}}-\rho\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{(z^2+\rho^2)^{3/2}} dE=4πϵ0​dq​(z2+ρ2)3/2zz^−ρcos(ϕ)x^−ρcos(ϕ)y^​​

We want to integrate, so need to write d q dq dq in terms of coordinates. On the disk, a small patch has an area of ( ρ d ϕ ) ( d ρ ) (\rho d\phi)(d\rho) (ρdϕ)(dρ), so d q = σ ( ρ d ϕ ) ( d ρ ) dq=\sigma (\rho d\phi)(d\rho) dq=σ(ρdϕ)(dρ)

where ρ \rho ρ and ϕ \phi ϕ are polar coordinates. This gives E = ∫ 0 2 π ∫ 0 a σ ρ d ϕ d ρ 4 π ϵ 0 z z ^ − ρ cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) x ^ − ρ cos ⁡ ( ϕ ) y ^ ( z 2 + ρ 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E} = \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^a \frac{\sigma \rho d\phi d\rho}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{z\hat{\mathbf{z}}-\rho\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{x}}-\rho\cos(\phi)\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{(z^2+\rho^2)^{3/2}} E=∫02π​∫0a​4πϵ0​σρdϕdρ​(z2+ρ2)3/2zz^−ρcos(ϕ)x^−ρcos(ϕ)y^​​

Based on the symmetry argument that we can always find another d q dq dq that exactly cancels the horizontal component of a given d q dq dq, we expect the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ terms to be zero, so we can drop them. Or we can notice that after factoring out everything that does not depend on ϕ \phi ϕ, the integrals for the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ terms are cos ⁡ ϕ , d ϕ \cos\phi,d\phi cosϕ,dϕ and sin ⁡ ϕ , d ϕ \sin\phi,d\phi sinϕ,dϕ from 0 0 0 to 2 π 2\pi 2π, which are both zero. Note that if a 1/2 disk was given, the integral limits would be from 0 0 0 to π \pi π, and one of the integrals would not be zero.

(2)  E = ∫ 0 2 π ∫ 0 a σ ρ d ϕ d ρ 4 π ϵ 0 z z ^ ( z 2 + ρ 2 ) 3 / 2 \text{(2) }\mathbf{E} = \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^a \frac{\sigma \rho d\phi d\rho}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{(z^2+\rho^2)^{3/2}} (2) E=∫02π​∫0a​4πϵ0​σρdϕdρ​(z2+ρ2)3/2zz^​

Equation (2) is an acceptable answer for this problem. Equation (2) is the equation that you would get if you integrated the contributions from rings of various radii.

If you have other problems to work on, do them first before reading the following.

In the following, I’ll fill in the steps required in order to verify that the result of (2) matches the predictions for z < < a z<<a z<<a and z > > a z>>a z>>a, which is not something that would be asked on an exam. On an exam, you should be able to recognize that for z < < a z<<a z<<a, the final answer should be the same as that for a sheet of charge and for z > > a z>>a z>>a, the final answer should be the same as if all of the charge on the disk was concentrated at the origin. Part of the motivation of identifying how the solution should behave in limiting cases is that a lot can go wrong while developing the solution. These limits give you a way to check your final answer.

Factoring out the constants in (2) gives E = σ z z ^ 4 π ϵ 0 ∫ 0 2 π ∫ 0 a ρ d ϕ d ρ ( z 2 + ρ 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E} = \frac{\sigma z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^a \frac{\rho d\phi d\rho}{(z^2+\rho^2)^{3/2}} E=4πϵ0​σzz^​∫02π​∫0a​(z2+ρ2)3/2ρdϕdρ​

Nothing in the integrand depends on ϕ \phi ϕ, so the ϕ \phi ϕ integral redues to 2 π 2\pi 2π E = 2 π σ z z ^ 4 π ϵ 0 ∫ 0 a ρ d ρ ( z 2 + ρ 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E} = \frac{2\pi\sigma z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \int_0^a \frac{\rho d\rho}{(z^2+\rho^2)^{3/2}} E=4πϵ0​2πσzz^​∫0a​(z2+ρ2)3/2ρdρ​

The result of the integration gives the final answer (to integrate, use a substitution of u 2 = ρ 2 + z 2 u^2=\rho^2+z^2 u2=ρ2+z2 and remember that z 2 = ∣ z ∣ \sqrt{z^2}=|z| z2​=∣z∣). (3)  E = σ z 2 ϵ 0 ( 1 ∣ z ∣ − 1 a 2 + z 2 ) z ^ \text{(3) }\mathbf{E} = \frac{\sigma z}{2\epsilon_0} \left(\frac{1}{|z|}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{a^2+z^2}}\right)\hat{\mathbf{z}} (3) E=2ϵ0​σz​(∣z∣1​−a2+z2​1​)z^

For z < < a z<<a z<<a, only the first term in parenthesis is large E = σ 2 ϵ 0 z ∣ z ∣ z ^ \mathbf{E} = \frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}\frac{z}{|z|}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E=2ϵ0​σ​∣z∣z​z^

Notice how the z ∣ z ∣ \frac{z}{|z|} ∣z∣z​ term tells use the direction of the electric field. When z > 0 z>0 z>0, this term is + 1 +1 +1. When z < 0 z<0 z<0, this term is − 1 -1 −1.

For z > > a z>>a z>>a, we need to do a bit more work on the second term in parentheses in (3). Factor out a z z z from the square root to get E = σ z 2 ϵ 0 ( 1 ∣ z ∣ − 1 ∣ z ∣ 1 + a 2 / z 2 ) z ^ \mathbf{E} = \frac{\sigma z}{2\epsilon_0} \left(\frac{1}{|z|}-\frac{1}{|z|\sqrt{1+a^2/z^2}}\right)\hat{\mathbf{z}} E=2ϵ0​σz​(∣z∣1​−∣z∣1+a2/z2​1​)z^

Because a / z < < 1 a/z << 1 a/z<<1, we can use the binomial expansion to get E ≃ σ z 2 ϵ 0 [ 1 ∣ z ∣ − 1 ∣ z ∣ ( 1 − a 2 2 z 2 ) ] z ^ \mathbf{E} \simeq \frac{\sigma z}{2\epsilon_0} \left[\frac{1}{|z|}-\frac{1}{|z|}\left(1-\frac{a^2}{2z^2}\right)\right]\hat{\mathbf{z}} E≃2ϵ0​σz​[∣z∣1​−∣z∣1​(1−2z2a2​)]z^

Simplifying gives E ≃ σ 2 ϵ 0 a 2 2 z 2 z ∣ z ∣ z ^ \mathbf{E} \simeq \frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0} \frac{a^2}{2z^2}\frac{z}{|z|}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E≃2ϵ0​σ​2z2a2​∣z∣z​z^

To show that in this limit the result is the same as if all of the charge was at the origin, we need to compute the charge on the disk, which is q = σ π a 2 q=\sigma\pi a^2 q=σπa2

Subtituing for σ \sigma σ gives E ≃ σ 2 ϵ 0 a 2 2 z 2 z ∣ z ∣ z ^ \mathbf{E} \simeq \frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0} \frac{a^2}{2z^2}\frac{z}{|z|}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E≃2ϵ0​σ​2z2a2​∣z∣z​z^

Simplifying gives E ≃ q 4 π ϵ 0 1 z 2 z ∣ z ∣ z ^ \mathbf{E} \simeq \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{1}{z^2}\frac{z}{|z|}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E≃4πϵ0​q​z21​∣z∣z​z^

4. At points close to the center of the disk and just above and below it the disk “looks” like an infinite sheet. So we expect the solution to be the same as an infinite sheet of charge, for which E = σ z ^ / ( 2 ϵ 0 ) \mathbf{E}=\sigma\hat{\mathbf{z}}/(2\epsilon_0) E=σz^/(2ϵ0​).

5. On the z z z-axis and for z > > a z>>a z>>a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E, and why?

Very far away from the disk (with respect to a a a, of course), the disk “looks” like a small point charge at the origin. The total charge on the disk is q = σ π a 2 q=\sigma\pi a^2 q=σπa2, so one expects E = k q z ^ / z 2 = k σ π a 2 z ^ / z 2 \mathbf{E}=kq\hat{\mathbf{z}}/z^2=k\sigma\pi a^2\hat{\mathbf{z}}/z^2 E=kqz^/z2=kσπa2z^/z2.

6. It does not technically make sense to ask “on the z z z-axis and for large z z z, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E?”. Why?

An ant’s “large” z z z, say 12 inches, could be the same z z z as what a whale would call a “small” z z z. This is why one always writes equations that indicate what “large” is relative to, e.g., z > > a z>>a z>>a.

0.10 Cylinder of Charge

A hollow cylinder of radius a a a has its axis along the z z z-axis, extends from z = 0 z=0 z=0 to z = − L z=-L z=−L, and has a surface charge of σ 0 \sigma_0 σ0​.

  1. If L < < a L<<a L<<a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E at z = 0 z=0 z=0?

  2. At z = − L / 2 z=-L/2 z=−L/2, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E?

  3. Find V ( z ) V(z) V(z)

  4. Find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z)

0.11 Disk of Charge

A disk of charge with a charge density of σ \sigma σ has a radius a a a, is centered at the origin, and lies in the x − y x-y x−y plane.

  1. What is the expected direction of E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) for z > 0 z>0 z>0 and for z < 0 z < 0 z<0?

  2. For z > > a z >> a z>>a, what should E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) approach? (Give exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system given in the problem.)

  3. For z < < a z << a z<<a, what should E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) approach? (Give exact equation in terms of the parameters and coordinate system given in the problem.)

  4. Find the integral for E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z), solve it, and verify that the solution satisfies your answers to 1. , 2., and 3. Solve this problem using [[F19/Notes#Continuous_Charge_Distributions|the steps in the notes]]. There is a simplification for this problem that is given in textbook solutions (similar to the ring of charge problem) - do not use this simplification. Eventually, I’ll ask you for the electric field at points off of the z z z-axis, and this simplification won’t work.

Answer

  1. E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) should be in + z ^ +\hat{\mathbf{z}} +z^ direction for z > 0 z>0 z>0 and in − z ^ -\hat{\mathbf{z}} −z^ direction for z > 0 z>0 z>0.

  2. For z > > a z>>a z>>a, looks like a point charge at the origin with electric field magnitude of E = k q / z 2 E=kq/z^2 E=kq/z2 with a direction given by the answer to 1. In terms of the parameters given in the problem, q = π a 2 σ q=\pi a^2 \sigma q=πa2σ, so E = ( σ a 2 / 4 ϵ o ) / z 2 E=(\sigma a^2/4\epsilon_o)/z^2 E=(σa2/4ϵo​)/z2.

  3. For z < < a z<<a z<<a, looks like an infinite sheet of charge, for which E = σ / 2 ϵ o E=\sigma/2\epsilon_o E=σ/2ϵo​ and direction given by the answer to 1.

  4. The set-up for this part is similar to the ring of charge.

In the ring of charge, the charges were on a small line segment with d l ′ = a d s ′ d ϕ ′ dl' = ads'd\phi' dl′=ads′dϕ′ so that d q ′ = λ d l ′ dq'=\lambda dl' dq′=λdl′

In this problem, the charges are on a patch of area with d A = s ′ d s ′ d ϕ ′ dA=s'ds'd\phi' dA=s′ds′dϕ′.

In the ring of charge, r ′ = a cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + a sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ \mathbf{r}'=a\cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}}+a\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} r′=acosϕx^+asinϕy^​.

In this problem, the distance to the d q ′ dq' dq′s is not fixed at a a a, but rather depends on s s s according to r ′ = s ′ cos ⁡ ϕ ′ x ^ + s ′ sin ⁡ ϕ ′ y ^ \mathbf{r}'=s'\cos\phi'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+s'\sin\phi'\hat{\mathbf{y}} r′=s′cosϕ′x^+s′sinϕ′y^​.

After some algebra, you should get

E ( z ) = σ z z ^ 4 π ϵ 0 ∫ 0 2 π ∫ 0 a s ′ d ϕ ′ d s ′ ( z 2 + s ′ 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}(z) = \frac{\sigma z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^a \frac{s' d\phi' ds'}{(z^2+s'^2)^{3/2}} E(z)=4πϵ0​σzz^​∫02π​∫0a​(z2+s′2)3/2s′dϕ′ds′​

Nothing in the integrand depends on ϕ ′ \phi' ϕ′, so the ϕ ′ \phi' ϕ′ integral reduces to 2 π 2\pi 2π

E ( z ) = 2 π σ z z ^ 4 π ϵ 0 ∫ 0 a s ′ d s ′ ( z 2 + s ′ 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}(z) = \frac{2\pi\sigma z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \int_0^a \frac{s' ds'}{(z^2+s'^2)^{3/2}} E(z)=4πϵ0​2πσzz^​∫0a​(z2+s′2)3/2s′ds′​

The result of the integration gives the final answer (to integrate, use a substitution of u 2 = s ′ 2 + z 2 u^2=s'^2+z^2 u2=s′2+z2 and remember that z 2 = ∣ z ∣ \sqrt{z^2}=|z| z2​=∣z∣).

(1) E ( z ) = σ z 2 ϵ 0 ( 1 ∣ z ∣ − 1 a 2 + z 2 ) z ^ \text{(1)}\qquad\mathbf{E}(z) = \frac{\sigma z}{2\epsilon_0} \left(\frac{1}{|z|}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{a^2+z^2}}\right)\hat{\mathbf{z}} (1)E(z)=2ϵ0​σz​(∣z∣1​−a2+z2​1​)z^

I gave full credit if you were able to get this equation.

The point of questions 1.-3. was to provide a check to your math for part 4. These checks were not asked for but are given below.

For z < < a z<<a z<<a, only the first term in parenthesis is large

E = σ 2 ϵ 0 z ∣ z ∣ z ^ \mathbf{E} = \frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}\frac{z}{|z|}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E=2ϵ0​σ​∣z∣z​z^

Notice how the z ∣ z ∣ \frac{z}{|z|} ∣z∣z​ term tells use the direction of the electric field. When z > 0 z>0 z>0, this term is + 1 +1 +1. When z < 0 z<0 z<0, this term is − 1 -1 −1. Also note how this matches the answer to question 3.

For z > > a z>>a z>>a, we need to do a bit more work on the second term in parentheses in (1). Factor out a z z z from the square root to get

E = σ z 2 ϵ 0 ( 1 ∣ z ∣ − 1 ∣ z ∣ 1 + a 2 / z 2 ) z ^ \mathbf{E} = \frac{\sigma z}{2\epsilon_0} \left(\frac{1}{|z|}-\frac{1}{|z|\sqrt{1+a^2/z^2}}\right)\hat{\mathbf{z}} E=2ϵ0​σz​(∣z∣1​−∣z∣1+a2/z2​1​)z^

Because a / z < < 1 a/z << 1 a/z<<1, we can use the binomial expansion to get

E ≃ σ z 2 ϵ 0 [ 1 ∣ z ∣ − 1 ∣ z ∣ ( 1 − a 2 2 z 2 ) ] z ^ \mathbf{E} \simeq \frac{\sigma z}{2\epsilon_0} \left[\frac{1}{|z|}-\frac{1}{|z|}\left(1-\frac{a^2}{2z^2}\right)\right]\hat{\mathbf{z}} E≃2ϵ0​σz​[∣z∣1​−∣z∣1​(1−2z2a2​)]z^

Simplifying gives

E ≃ σ 2 ϵ 0 a 2 2 z 2 z ∣ z ∣ z ^ \mathbf{E} \simeq \frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0} \frac{a^2}{2z^2}\frac{z}{|z|}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E≃2ϵ0​σ​2z2a2​∣z∣z​z^

which matches the prediction from 2.

0.12 Shell of Charge

A shell centered at the origin and having a radius of a a a has a charge Q Q Q uniformly spread over it.

Although E \mathbf{E} E and V V V can be computed using Gauss’ Law, answer the first two problems using the method used for computing the electric potential and electric field that you would use for the previous charged disk problem.

1. Find V V V on the z z z-axis in terms of constants times a single integral. 2. Find E \mathbf{E} E on the z z z-axis in terms of constants and optionally times one or more integrals. 3. At the origin, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E, and why? 4. On the z z z-axis and for z ≲ a z\lesssim a z≲a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E, and why? 5. On the z z z-axis and for z ≳ a z\gtrsim a z≳a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E, and why? 6. On the z z z-axis and for z > > a z>> a z>>a, what is expected for E \mathbf{E} E, and why? 7. If this question was modified to ask you for answers along the x x x or y y y axis, how would your answers change?

All final equations should be expressed in terms of k k k or ϵ 0 , Q \epsilon_0,Q ϵ0​,Q, and a a a using any coordinate system.

0.13 Square of Charge

A square non-conducting sheet of charge with side length w w w has a uniform charge density of σ o \sigma_o σo​, lies in the x − y x-y x−y plane, and is centered on the origin.

1. Find an integral or integrals that must be evaluated to find E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z), the electric field on the z z z-axis. 2. Evaluate the integral or integrals and show that for z / w ≪ 1 z/w\ll 1 z/w≪1, E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) reduces to the equation for an infinite non-conducting sheet of charge.

Solution

There are several ways to solve this problem. On can first find the field for a line of charge with a charge density of λ \lambda λ and length w w w that lies on the x x x-axis and is centered on the origin - the result is (see Griffiths 4th Edition example 2.2):

E ( z ) = k λ w z z 2 + w 2 / 4 z ^ \mathbf{E}(z)=\frac{k\lambda w}{z\sqrt{z^2+w^2/4}}\hat{\mathbf{z}} E(z)=zz2+w2/4​kλw​z^

Then integrate the field due to differential lines of charges. One needs to account for the fact that the z z z in this equation will not be the same as the z z z in this problem. If the differential lines of charge are in the x x x- y y y plane and lie on the line x = x ′ x=x' x=x′, then replace the z z z with z 2 + x ′ 2 z^2+x'^2 z2+x′2 and use λ = σ o d x ′ \lambda = \sigma_odx' λ=σo​dx′, You can check your answer for this approach by using the result of the following approach after integration with respect to x ′ x' x′.

E d q ′ ( x , y , z ) = d q ′ 4 π ϵ 0 ԉ ^ ԉ 2 \mathbf{E}_{dq'}(x,y,z) = \frac{dq'}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}}{\char"0509^2} Edq′​(x,y,z)=4πϵ0​dq′​ԉ2ԉ^​

A second approach requires two integrations. Start with

E d q ′ ( x , y , z ) = d q ′ 4 π ϵ 0 ԉ ^ ԉ 2 \mathbf{E}_{dq'}(x,y,z) = \frac{dq'}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}}{{\char"0509}^2}Edq′​(x,y,z)=4πϵ0​dq′​ԉ2ԉ^​

which expands to

Edq′(x,y,z)=dq′4πϵ0r−r′∣r−r′∣3\mathbf{E}_{dq'}(x,y,z) =\frac{dq'}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|^3}Edq′​(x,y,z)=4πϵ0​dq′​∣r−r′∣3r−r′​

(A third approach is to find the potential Ψdq′(x,y,z)=dq′/(4πϵ0ԉ)\Psi_{dq'}(x,y,z) = dq'/(4\pi\epsilon_0{\char"0509})Ψdq′​(x,y,z)=dq′/(4πϵ0​ԉ) and then use E=−∇Ψ\mathbf{E}=-\nabla \PsiE=−∇Ψ.)

and the general definitions

r=xx^+yy^+zz^\mathbf{r}=x\hat{\mathbf{x}}+y\hat{\mathbf{y}}+z\hat{\mathbf{z}} r=xx^+yy^​+zz^

r ′ = x ′ x ^ + y ′ y ^ + z ′ z ^ \mathbf{r}'=x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+y'\hat{\mathbf{y}}+z'\hat{\mathbf{z}} r′=x′x^+y′y^​+z′z^

In this problem, z ′ = 0 z'=0 z′=0 because all charges are in the x − y x-y x−y plane. Using d q ′ = σ o d x ′ d y ′ dq' = \sigma_odx'dy' dq′=σo​dx′dy′, gives

E ( x , y , z ) = ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 σ o d x ′ d y ′ 4 π ϵ 0 ( x − x ′ ) x ^ + ( y − y ′ ) y ^ + z z ^ ( ( x − x ′ ) 2 + ( y − y ′ ) 2 + z 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}(x,y,z) = \int_{-w/2}^{w/2}\int_{-w/2}^{w/2}\frac{ \sigma_odx'dy'}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{(x-x')\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(y-y')\hat{\mathbf{y}}+z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{\big((x-x')^2+(y-y')^2+z^2\big)^{3/2}} E(x,y,z)=∫−w/2w/2​∫−w/2w/2​4πϵ0​σo​dx′dy′​((x−x′)2+(y−y′)2+z2)3/2(x−x′)x^+(y−y′)y^​+zz^​

E ( z ) \mathbf{E}(z) E(z) is obtained by setting x = y = 0 x=y=0 x=y=0:

E ( z ) = ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 σ o d x ′ d y ′ 4 π ϵ 0 − x ′ x ^ + − y ′ y ^ + z z ^ ( x ′ 2 + y ′ 2 + z 2 ) 3 / 2 \mathbf{E}(z) = \int_{-w/2}^{w/2}\int_{-w/2}^{w/2}\frac{ \sigma_odx'dy'}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{-x'\hat{\mathbf{x}}+-y'\hat{\mathbf{y}}+z\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{\big(x'^2+y'^2+z^2\big)^{3/2}} E(z)=∫−w/2w/2​∫−w/2w/2​4πϵ0​σo​dx′dy′​(x′2+y′2+z2)3/2−x′x^+−y′y^​+zz^​

The x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ integrals are zero because their integrands are odd functions. Many students argued they are zero “by symmetry”. The word “symmetry” is too general because there are many types of symmetry. It is better to state what kind of symmetry: consider differential charges at ( x , y ) (x,y) (x,y) and ( − x , − y ) (-x,-y) (−x,−y) - their horizontal electric fields exactly cancel (ideally provide a diagram). The sheet of charge can be constructed by placing charges with canceling horizontal components and so the horizontal electric field is zero.

To simplify the integration for the y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ term, define

I = ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 d y ′ ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 d x ′ ( x ′ 2 + a 2 ) 3 / 2 I = \int_{-w/2}^{w/2}dy'\int_{-w/2}^{w/2}\frac{dx'}{(x'^2+a^2)^{3/2}} I=∫−w/2w/2​dy′∫−w/2w/2​(x′2+a2)3/2dx′​

where a 2 ≡ y ′ 2 + z 2 a^2\equiv y'^2+z^2 a2≡y′2+z2 and then E z ( z ) = k σ o z I E_z(z)=k\sigma_ozI Ez​(z)=kσo​zI. This integral can be looked up or found using Mathematica or Wolfram Alpha. Some students reported “computation time exceeded” with Wolfram Alpha. This was probably caused by entering the double integral instead of doing a single integral at a time.

Integration with respect to x ′ x' x′ gives

I = ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 d y ′ x ′ a 2 ( x ′ 2 + a 2 ) 1 / 2 ∣ − w / 2 w / 2 = ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 d y ′ w a 2 ( a 2 + w 2 / 4 ) 1 / 2 I= \int_{-w/2}^{w/2}dy'\frac{x'}{a^2(x'^2+a^2)^{1/2}}\Bigg|_{-w/2}^{w/2}=\int_{-w/2}^{w/2}dy'\frac{w}{a^2(a^2+w^2/4)^{1/2}} I=∫−w/2w/2​dy′a2(x′2+a2)1/2x′​∣∣​−w/2w/2​=∫−w/2w/2​dy′a2(a2+w2/4)1/2w​

Using the earlier definition a 2 ≡ y ′ 2 + z 2 a^2\equiv y'^2+z^2 a2≡y′2+z2 and a new definition b 2 ≡ z 2 + w 2 / 4 b^2\equiv z^2+w^2/4 b2≡z2+w2/4 gives

I = ∫ − w / 2 w / 2 w d y ′ ( y ′ 2 + z 2 ) y ′ 2 + b 2 I=\int_{-w/2}^{w/2}\frac{wdy'}{(y'^2+z^2)\sqrt{y'^2+b^2}} I=∫−w/2w/2​(y′2+z2)y′2+b2​wdy′​

This integral can be looked up and the result is (using tan ⁡ − 1 ( u ) = − tan ⁡ − 1 ( u ) \tan^{-1}(u)=-\tan^{-1}(u) tan−1(u)=−tan−1(u))

I = 4 z tan ⁡ − 1 [ w 2 4 z 1 z 2 + w 2 / 2 ] I=\frac{4}{z}\tan^{-1}\left[\frac{w^2}{4z}\frac{1}{\sqrt{z^2+w^2/2}}\right] I=z4​tan−1[4zw2​z2+w2/2​1​]

The final result, using E z ( z ) = k σ o z I E_z(z)=k\sigma_ozI Ez​(z)=kσo​zI defined earlier, is

E z ( z ) = σ o π ϵ o tan ⁡ − 1 [ w 2 4 z 1 z 2 + w 2 / 2 ] E_z(z)=\frac{\sigma_o}{\pi \epsilon_o}\tan^{-1}\left[\frac{w^2}{4z}\frac{1}{\sqrt{z^2+w^2/2}}\right] Ez​(z)=πϵo​σo​​tan−1[4zw2​z2+w2/2​1​]

For z ≪ w z\ll w z≪w, the argument to the inverse tangent is

w 2 4 z 1 z 2 + w 2 / 2 ≃ w z 2 4 \frac{w^2}{4z}\frac{1}{\sqrt{z^2+w^2/2}}\simeq \frac{w}{z}\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4} 4zw2​z2+w2/2​1​≃zw​42​​

so for z > 0 z \gt 0 z>0 and z ≪ w z\ll w z≪w

E z ( z ) → σ o π ϵ o tan ⁡ − 1 ( + ∞ ) = σ o 2 ϵ o E_z(z)\rightarrow\frac{\sigma_o}{\pi\epsilon_o}\tan^{-1}(+\infty) = \frac{\sigma_o}{2\epsilon_o} Ez​(z)→πϵo​σo​​tan−1(+∞)=2ϵo​σo​​

For z < 0 z \lt 0 z<0 and z ≪ w z\ll w z≪w

E z ( z ) → σ o π ϵ o tan ⁡ − 1 ( − ∞ ) = − σ o 2 ϵ o E_z(z)\rightarrow\frac{\sigma_o}{\pi\epsilon_o}\tan^{-1}(-\infty) = -\frac{\sigma_o}{2\epsilon_o} Ez​(z)→πϵo​σo​​tan−1(−∞)=−2ϵo​σo​​

and so the solution matches that for an infinite sheet of charge. Another problem one could ask is to show that for z ≫ w z\gg w z≫w, E z → k σ o w 2 / z 2 E_z\rightarrow k\sigma_ow^2/z^2 Ez​→kσo​w2/z2 (far away, the sheet of charge appears as a charge σ o w 2 \sigma_ow^2 σo​w2 at the origin). To show this, one would need to Taylor series expand the argument of the inverse tangent for small w / z w/z w/z.

0.14 Quarter circle

Compute E \mathbf{E} E at the center of quarter circle.
